title: If the MacBook Pro‚Äôs notch is in the way, you can hide it
content:
With the¬†14- and 16-inch MacBook Pro, Apple took a note from the iPhone and added a notch at the top of the display that houses the FaceTime camera. Also like the iPhone, Apple decided to fill the space around the notch with the menu bar.

Update 10/28: Apple has posted an official support document regarding the notch.

For most people, it won‚Äôt be an issue. Unless you‚Äôre the kind of person who uses a lot of menu bar icons or runs their screen at a larger resolution, menu bar items will simply occupy the space to the right of the notch, and menu items will stick to the left. However, since the macOS menu bar is much more customizable and versatile than the iPhone‚Äôs status bar, some apps with lengthy menus could cause issues, as evidenced by a viral tweet that made the rounds this week:

In its Human Interface Guidelines, Apple is urging developers to make menus less of an issue with the notch by favoring ‚Äúshort, one-word menu titles.‚Äù¬†As Apple explains, ‚ÄúA short, single-word app name (and) ‚Ä¶ one-word menu titles work especially well in the menu bar because they take little space and are easy for people to scan.‚Äù

Additionally, the funky menu bar extra behavior in the tweet will also hopefully be fixed. Apple is encouraging ‚Äúexposing app-specific functionality in other ways‚Äù such as the Dock. It‚Äôll take time and there will be some pushback, but over the course of the next several months, jumping menus and obscured menu bar extras should become less of an issue.

In the meantime, Apple has provided a fix of sorts. When you‚Äôre in full-screen mode, you have the option to display the menu bar¬†under¬†the notch with a black strip around the notch. This is handy if the app you‚Äôre using isn‚Äôt displaying the menu properly while in full-screen mode but you‚Äôll lose some screen real estate.

To activate this, click on an app‚Äôs icon in the Finder and Get Info on it (Command+I on your keyboard, or go to¬†File¬†>¬†Get Info). If it‚Äôs available, you‚Äôll find an option in the General section to ‚ÄúScale to fit below built-in camera.‚Äù Check that box, close Get Info, and then when you launch the app and go into full-screen mode, the menu bar will be positioned under the notch.

IDG

According to Apple‚Äôs Developer Documentation for User Interface, this setting shows up if a developer doesn‚Äôt write their software to switch on its own. If a developer decides to write their software to use the mode they deem best for their app, the option is not available. Some of the apps that we found with this option so far include Final Cut Pro, Logic Pro, Xcode, iMovie, GarageBand, the iWork apps, Adobe Premiere Pro 2021, Affinity Photo, Civilization VI, Cisco Webex Meetings, Spitfire Audio, and Cinema 4D. It‚Äôs entirely possible that those apps and others will be updated by their developers to use a preferred mode.

As noted in our full review of the 14-inch M1 Pro MacBook Pro, the notch doesn‚Äôt technically infringe on the MacBook Pro‚Äôs screen area. The screen below the notch is a 16-by-10 space like before, and the notch and screen on each side of it are ‚Äúextra‚Äù space. When the menu bar is placed in that notch area, it‚Äôs actually giving you more room to work with than the previous MacBook Pro displays.

In case you‚Äôre wondering, this option is not available for the macOS Monterey Finder, which is basically an app that runs in full-screen mode all the time. So you can‚Äôt block out the notch by default, at least for now.

IDG

As far as menu bar extras, Apple will only allow them to fill the right side of the notch, and will only show what can fit. So if you use numerous extras, some might go missing: ‚ÄúWhen menu bar space is constrained, the system prioritizes the display of menu bar menus, as well as essential menu bar extras, such as Clock. To ensure that menus remain readable, the system may decrease the space between the titles, truncating them if necessary.‚Äù

There are also utilities that will remove the notch, such as Top Notch and Forehead. We‚Äôre sure there will be many others to come.
author: Roman Loyola
